reviewText: The original Slender, released in the summer of 2012, was an experimental horror game that dropped you into a spooky forest with nothing but a flashlight to guide your way and a faceless entity known as the Slender Man following your every step. Despite having rough, simple graphics, it was a chilling gameplay experience. Slender: The Arrival, a reimagining of the original game, once again sets players up to encounter the enigmatic Slender Man, this time with a much more robust story, improved visual design, and just as many scares.The Arrival has you play as Lauren, a young woman who is visiting her friend Kate. Kate is selling her isolated family home after her mother's death, but upon your arrival, you find Kate's house mysteriously empty. The doors are wide open, there's furniture knocked around, and there's several mysterious notes about repressed memories and hallucinations... then you see a strange figure watching you from outside the window. It isn't long before you realize something terrible has happened to Kate, and it's up to you to find out where she is and why she disappeared.One of the first things you'll notice about The Arrival is that along with a significantly overhauled visual design compared to the original, it features a very dark and foreboding atmosphere that does an excellent job of keeping you on edge, if not outright terrified. Whether its hunting down those eight infamous pages in the remake of the original forest level from Slender, or scrambling to turn on an elevator in an abandoned mining facility, you'll rarely feel that you're in a safe enough spot to stand still and catch your breath. Much like the original game, you're almost completely defenseless, and all you have with you is a flashlight and the ability to sprint for short distances. However, you'll have to worry about how often you use your light and how much noise you make, since your pursuers rely on both to track you down. Deciding between whether you should try being stealthy and risk getting lost in the dark environment, or dashing to your objectives as fast as possible knowing that you're more likely to run right into the Slender Man's open arms, can be an unnerving choice to make. The implacable Slender Man is as imposing and aggressive a foe as ever, and often the only notice you'll have that he's caught up to you is a slight distortion that ripples across your screen... occasionally followed by him flashing directly in front of you in a cacophony of digital noise and electronic screams.While the stages do have randomness to them in the form of starting locations, landmarks or key items being different each time you play through a stage, most feel like they could have had more variety. Almost all follow a similar formula of find X number of objects while trying not to die horrifically." What really hurts The Arrival the most

reviewText:
Imagine it, you're walking down a dirt road in the woods at dusk, it is autumn the leaves are turning orange and red. You come across an abandon vehicle on the road. The sun quickly sets, leaving you in the dark without a flashlight and suddenly, you aren't alone anymore. You are being watched and stalked by something. It feeds off of the power of your video camera, which is the only way to see it (I guess).

When your video camera flickers, it is closing in on you. It is drawing the power from the batteries as it draws near. It is Slenderman. A tall thin humanoid creature that looks over you from afar from hilltops. The creature that opens the doors that you just closed. The creature that your only defense is to not look at it. To wish it away as you cower in fear by looking at the ground. No... just run away until your video recorder stops flickering. How do you run from something that just teleports in front of you? You can always walk backward.

This is Slender: The Arrival, less of a game and more of a first person experience along the lines of Dear Esther and Gone Home. It preys on your fears. It has a great, creepy atmosphere and great sound design. You have little in the way of controls, left stick to move, right stick to look, a sprint button, flashlight button, zoom button, and a use button. There are other buttons, but they feel redundant.

The game dumps you in and never explains why you're there. Not just the first chapter of the game, but over and over again, its the same thing, you start at dusk in the woods and go into the night and then find an abandon building. Each chapter has a different task, such as turn on X generators, find X pages in the woods and close X windows. Simple things, but you're just stuck with something that can be anywhere at anytime that will warn you when its near. The more things you collect, the more intensely you will be harassed.

As you wander in the dark you quickly come across an average house. Depending on where you enter, it looks like there is nothing wrong. Just a normal house for sale with a playground in the back. Soon enough you'll find things scrawled on the walls and rooms in disarray. Eventually, you'll find a flashlight that will help you. The idea of wandering in the woods might seem like an easy way to get lost, but as you roam the darkness, you'll be enticed by audio and visual cues such as paths, lights and dozens of arrows pointing in one direction that will guide your way.

If you think you'll get used to Slenderman, once you progress far enough, eventually you will reach an abandon facility and have a follower. Perhaps it is a follower of the Slenderman, but it follows, chases and strangles you. This isn't a creature like Slenderman, so it doesn't have magical powers other than it is getting closer, running after you. You'll hear its footsteps running up to you. Your only defense is to focus your flashlight and blind it. That adds something different to the game. Getting trapped in a side room means there is no way out and no where to run away from the follower.

It is a toss up if this experience is for you. If finding stuff in the dark isn't for you then skip it. You'll be searching open areas for sometimes tiny things (sheets of paper). Lost in the woods and abandon buildings. Being thrown off your direction from having to run away and forced to figure out where you're going again in an area that is mostly woods. If you can't handle bobbing and weaving cameras, avoid this game. It might be a nitpick but sometimes the camera seems to be at a person's waist. The height of a sink or a doorknob.

I couldn't really recommend Dear Esther or Gone Home. They were both beautiful and immersive, but I didn't feel anything playing those games like I did with Slender: The Arrival. Is it worth $10 for an hour or two of gameplay? I feel like I was engaged and always challenged by a single strange foe with powers to teleport anywhere.

reviewText:
Slender: The Arrival is a first person adventure game. You are only equipped with a flashlight. You have to explore various locations and search for clues to your friend's whereabouts, while avoiding an unspeakable fate at the hands of Slender man himself. On your way you can pick up various papers that give you background information on the story, or clues.
There are no problems with controls and everything feels very smooth. The game itself is too short, it takes around 1 hour to finish.
The graphics are good, you will not be disappointed. Slender Man himself looks awesome, in my opinion this is the best Slender Man model of every Slender game. Everything else in the game, from the trees, to the rocks and so on looks pretty well, no complaints here.
The music is great, it really adds to the experience. You can hear that slow thumping in the background from the original Slender game when you pick up that first page in one of the levels. The sound effects are also good, sometimes you will hear the sounds of footsteps from someone or something other than you in the forest close by, or you will hear the Owls hooting at night, and other various forest sounds.
I can recommend Slender: The Arrival to people who wants a good fun scare or a nice horror game and of course all fans of the original Slender Man game. Fans of the original Slender will be happy to know that the original game is remade in one of the levels.

Sounds 8/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 6/10
Atmosphere 8/10

reviewText:
Slender: The Arrival is the follow-up to the popular freeware horror game, Slender: Eight Pages, being made by the people responsible for making Slender so popular (Mark J. Hadley, creator of Slender: Eight Pages, and the Marble Hornets team who made a series of Slender-themed YouTube videos). It's not just another Slender clone though, it goes for a more cinematic approach to gaming, and not as in fixed cutscenes or QTEs, but in providing an interactive cinematic horror experience.

The stories pretty simple. You are going to check in on a friend who lives deep in the forest who hasn't been responding to calls, texts, or emails for the last few days. Turns out, there's evil that lurks in these woods... Now can you escape?

Slender: The Arrival is probably the closest you'll get to playing a found-footage horror film in game form, at least yet. The way everything is told through the gameplay's lens, the 'folk-story' tone the game goes with the legend, the execution of how Slender and the events that transpire work, feels very much in-line with a found-footage horror film, except you are the driver and the one tasked with capturing it all and surviving.

In that regard, Slender: The Arrival is a very cool experience. It has some good build-up, atmosphere, and escalates the situation while still retaining a more down-to-earth feeling. All through gameplay, you experience a series of events and have to respond to them.

The basic Slender gameplay is still there... Collect different items and avoid the big tall man in the suit, but there's more to it here, and this is often where the split in opinion on this game begins.

The game is rather short, and honestly you probably spend more time just exploring places in-between the game's 'main' stages than you do actually playing the core Slender gameplay.This mainly involves going around locations, like a forest trail or a house, and opening doors to get to the next story location.

Slender: The Arrival is split into nine 'stages', five of them in the story, one as a secret hidden level, two of them were added post-patch to make a hidden new miniature story, and one as a bonus stage. Beating the story should take 2-4 hours the first time (the five main stages), and consist of two stages with you actually collecting items, two scenarios with you avoiding Slender via other means 'cinematically',  and most of these stages as well as one stage entirely having 'build-up' situations where nothing actually happens, but it builds-up to the next main gameplay scenario.

The length and the cinematic direction the game takes will turn some people off, but on my part it actually made me enjoy the game more. It legitimately feels like a playable found-footage horror film, and has charm and atmosphere in its design and oppressive stages. I found myself enjoying it during its short course.

I even got scared a few times, something the original Eight Pages and many Slender clones don't do to me. Scariness is subjective, but a feat I must mention as I don't actually find the character of Slender to be scary in general.

This said, I found myself more terrified by Slender's 'unidentified' masked assistant than Slender himself. She's a stalker who appears in a specific stage in the game, and her sounds, appearance, animations, and the environment you encounter her in legitimately made me afraid of her for a time.

However, for all of this 'cinematic charm' I'm spouting about, the game maybe alienated its main audience in some ways, as part of the charm of the original Slender game was with its minimalistic atmospheric gameplay and dreary feeling without need for story, explanation, and just throws you right in. This is a very different experience and very different game, and these changes completely alters the audience the game is designed for... And unfortunately, with a character who's been popularized like Slender, it can mean the game's audience is potentially very small, as some have come to ridicule or dislike his popularity and character, and those that like him may not like the way the game is designed differently and more aimed as a playable cinematic horror game.

I feel fond of it though, and it happens to be my favorite Slender-based game for the very reason of how its different. I find it to be enjoyable to play, and to experience, and craft an interesting world and scenario that was immersive to go through.

This all said, the best parts of the game maybe came out of the optional content. The 'bonus stage I mentioned is simply a recreation of the original Eight Pages game you can play outside of the main story, but a lot prettier. The game has difficulty levels and randomized features through all of its stages which is interesting. There are a variety of secrets and Easter eggs in the game, including a hidden ending.

The two post-patch stages based around a village and a farm take criticism from the game and made really moody set-pieces that add extra elements to the story, though finding them is a bit tricky as they require specific actions during the game's main story.

And for me, the absolute best part of the game was the secret level. I don't want to spoil it here, but at least for me, it was definitely the creepiest part of the whole game, but a shame most probably wouldn't find it without looking it up... It's pretty well hidden.

Slender The Arrival isn't for everybody and ditches the minimalist direction for something more akin to a game version of a found-footage horror film, but during its short duration it delivers an interesting different take on both Slender and cinematic horror games. I'd say worth a trip for those who think the idea of playing a found-footage horror film sounds appealing.

reviewText:
Game name: Slender: The Arrival
Reviewed by: Wolf

In Summary...Slender: The Arrival is a superb horror game made in succession to the popular indie game Slender: The Eight Pages by Mark J. Hadley in 2012. The story follows Lauren, who is investigating a disappearance of her friend Kate, after arriving at her home late one evening to find her missing. Racing through the levels uncovering more clues via pages, the story begins to unravel and you will soon learn Kate's fate. With 8 chapters and a secret level, this game delivers a horrifyingly stunning grasp on the tale of the Slender man.

Controls:WASD - move character.
Mouse - look around.
Left click - interact with objects.
Escape - pause.

Sounds:Slender: The Arrival is filled with horrifying sounds. If you've played the orginal title, you'll know when Slenderman gets near or is pursuing you, the screen becomes distorted and sharp noises peirce your ears. This can be especially jump-scare worthy in high-pressure moments, such as collecting the pages in Chapter 2, or turning on the generators in Chapter 3. Not only in addition to Slenderman, new characters are added in pursual of Lauren, meaning it's literally twice as scary! (bad pun intended)

Graphics:Substantial. If you have the time, feel free to check out the screenshots I've made with this game, they're absolutely phenomenal. I do, however; wish the graphics were supported to double the resolution such as the option in games like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter have.

Game Balance:It is very easy to win this game. I have played multiple times through, so I've learned which paths to take and how to avoid Slenderman and others in a proficient way. Newcomers may find it more difficult, and if playing on hardcore mode, adds a little bit more of a challenge to the game. Still hoping for a mode beyond hardcore though, preferably a veteran mode of some sorts with more appearances, no lighting, and no sprinting.

OtherFix achievements please. Currently there's a bug with the cloud saving, where if you resetstats in console, the game does not reset scrapbook nor steps, and deletes all achievements. This causes you to not be able to obtain the 10k steps achievement or the collector achievements. Easy fix = disable cloud saving. There's literally no need for a single player game like this.

Final Rating:8/10

In Conclusion:Absolutely a must have for any horror fan or veteran. This game offers a much more enticing tale and rivveting experience than the predecessor, The Eight Pages, as well as a much more stunning visual experience.

Please feel free to follow my curation page for more recommendations. Thanks for reading!

To conclude, Slender the Arrival is an interesting but short-lived psychological horror experience, that's worth checking out if you like a bit of  tension and meaningless scares. Remember Slender: the Eight Pages?
It basically was a level where you collect 8 spooky pages with child drawings, while being chased by so called Slenderman. And while nothing really special, it was pretty fun, atmospheric and scary.
Now, this game is basically the Eight Pages on steroids, which is both a good and bad thing...

Let's start with positives:  1.  Game is very atmospheric and it gives you feeling of hopelessness. Since you only have a flashlight and a camera, your only options of defence is running away with your tail between your legs.
2.  Sound design is pretty good. Wind blowing through trees, camera static, creepy ambient sounds and echoes sound pretty great.
3.  There is also a new enemy type that you will meet on a few levels, adding some variaty.
4.  If you are easily scared, you'll probably get your heart and adrenaline a nice little workout.
5.  Game got some love with patches and some new (and old) levels completely for free, which is nice

Now let's go over negatives and man, are there lot's of em:  1.  Story is basically non existent. You're there to find some boy or a girl, but why, where and when is never really explained, unless you find and read all the collectibles.
Even then I had to go to on the internet to get my story fix. I know, it's a scary simulator" but it is such a shame we don't get to know any of the rich lore behind Slenderman or ingame characters.
2.  If you're into horror games

A reasonably good horror game. It is easy to lose the plot a little but it almost does not matter as it is pretty obvious your aim is to find someone and not die in the process. My play through was pretty short, but I am told there are a number things I missed and it is possible another play through would let me find some different areas.

If you love horror games this is a must have game really, but keep your expectations at a mid level.

reviewText: Slender: The Arrival is an incredibly short game that, while capable of building an appropriate horror atmosphere, falls flat because of the fact that it relies almost exclusively on cheap, rule-based jumpscares to terrify its audience. As a result, just as in the original Slender: The Eight Pages, the potential horror quickly dissipates, giving way to the simple and shallow mechanic exercise of avoiding an exploitable enemy while collecting certain items to complete the level.\n\nThe jumpscares that this game relies so heavily upon can indeed be horrifying the first few times you experience them, but, because of the unavoidable repetition that they are condemned to, they rapidly become more of a nuisance than anything else.

reviewText:
While I can understand the hype behind the Slender myth as a social phenomenon I can't say the same for the game. Sure, Slender : The Arrival looks and plays better than its freeware counterparts but overall it's a disappointing game, especially if you put it next to Amnesia : The Dark Descent, a game that helped the renewal of the horror genre.

The first chapter managed to set up effectively a scary mood. Exploring the house and its surrounding was really stressful and made me felt really vulnerable. I always expected the worse. The second chapter is more like a remake of Slender : The Eight Pages. While the scare factor was still there the experience felt repetitive. The third chapter is certainly where the game went downhill. The little child is creepy the first time he jumps at you but after a while it gets repetitive and at the end we don't care anymore. The chapter where the events unravel from someone's else perspective was really surprising but at the same time it was too short. At the end of Chapter 6, we are left with an unexpected but disappointing conclusion. The game just lasted 1h 30min.

To summarize, the lack of work on the game design is what hurt Slender the most. Playing the game feels more like walking on an alley of jumpscare than facing dangerous threats.

Don't get me wrong. I'm not against the idea of a commercial Slender game. I just wish the game could be more polished since it has so much potential.

Hopefully, the next commercial Slender game on PC will get everything right.

reviewText:
Are you too afraid to play Slender: The Arrival, sequel to the PC horror hit that taught us to associate evening-wear with fatal outbreaks of screen static? Well, hereâ€™s how to overcome your terror: imagine that Slender Man himself is that awkward person you donâ€™t want to talk to at any given party. As with any social space invader, the guy's core tactic is to materialise silently in front of you, perhaps peeking shyly from behind an object, in hopes of catching your eye. The trick is to let your gaze slide over him to something else in the environment - hey, isnâ€™t that so-and-so from Marketing in the corner? - while stepping casually but firmly to one side.

OK, so itâ€™s not quite that simple. For starters, whenever Slender Man appears the screen goes nuts, stretching and splintering as though in the presence of an undersized black hole. Throw in all but perpetual nocturnal conditions and landscapes that are cluttered with loose objects, and youâ€™ll often struggle to pinpoint your adversaryâ€™s precise location.



More troublingly, Slender Manâ€™s the pushy type. The longer you succeed in escaping his clutches, and the more mission-critical items you collect, the more frequently heâ€™ll show up and the closer heâ€™ll get. And have we mentioned the context-sensitive score and audio effects? Because if that spidery, faceless guy in the suit doesnâ€™t give you the willies, the cacophonous, grating report that sometimes accompanies his entrance certainly will.

But what if youâ€™ve butted heads with Slender Man before? Well, The Arrivalâ€™s, er, arrival on Xbox One may struggle to impress. Itâ€™s largely the same game as on Xbox 360 with negligible visual enhancements and the same problem of diminishing returns. The jewel in the crown is the second level, a re-imagining of Slender: The Eight Pages in which you hunt for notes scattered around a forested area.



There are eight notes in total but 10 locations to investigate, some of which swap places between playthroughs, plus a selection of possible starting points, so no two sessions are alike. Prioritising areas in accordance with Slender Manâ€™s aggressiveness is critical: when heâ€™s at his most annoying, the last place you want to be is the Visitorâ€™s Centre, with its plethora of single-exit rooms. Thereâ€™s a run button to help you out of a jam, but itâ€™s tied to an invisible stamina bar thatâ€™s easy to exhaust when the pressure is on.

Sadly, the scenarios (some accessed by collecting or interacting with certain objects) that make up the remaining hour or two of playtime consist of slightly limp variations on a gambit that isnâ€™t nearly substantial enough to stand comparison with, say, fellow indie offering Outlast. The third level introduces a second foe who can be kept at bay with the beam of a flashlight; the echo of her footsteps through the depths of an abandoned mine is unnerving, but the basic explore-avoid-collect pattern is the same.



A later, more intriguing chapter takes place on a farm estate with some catacombs at one end and a deceptively picturesque cornfield in the middle. Itâ€™s relatively elaborate, but it wonâ€™t keep you busy for long.

If you like horror, but youâ€™ve yet to have the pleasure of Slender Manâ€™s company, his Xbox One incarnation is absolutely worth its budget price tag. The Eight Page template loses its bite with repeat exposure, but the gameâ€™s volatility remains invigorating given the genre's continued reliance on scripted scares and sheer grotesqueness. If youâ€™re a veteran of Slender, however, itâ€™s probably best to avoid eye contact. Thereâ€™s not enough meat on these bones.

This review is based on the Xbox One, Xbox 360 and PC versions of the game.

reviewText: This game is based on the phenomenon called Slender Man which was born in 2009 as a result of a photo contest announced in a forum. The name perfectly sums up who the antagonist is in these games - a slim, tall man wearing a black suit. Moreover, the creature in question is completely faceless just to add an even more terrifying look to it. Its author claims he was influenced by H.P. Lovecraft, Stephen King and even by the Tall Man from the Phantasm horror films when making Slender Man.\n\nNow, the first game was titled The Eight Pages and was released in 2012. Parsec Productions developed and released it on Windows completely independently from Steam. Blue Isle Studios, a Canadian developer company saw even more opportunity in the concept and released it under the name The Arrival. This now has a backstory to the game and, of course, includes the levels found in The Eight Pages. This sequel" was released in 2013 and since have become available on PS4 and Xbox One

reviewText:
Splain's View                                    For the full video review check here  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FO6IzXJg58k

Slender: The Arrival

Introduction â€“ Slender: The Arrival is a true survival horror game that focuses on atmosphere, creepy audio and mystery to set the player on edge throughout the duration of the game. The mystery will draw you in to make you want to learn more about what you are getting yourself into. It sticks to a very basic control scheme anyone can use. You can expect to finish the game in 3 hours of play, but there is decent replay value.

1.	Story â€“ 4/10 After fully beating the game once, I was still confused at what I just experienced. You read notes throughout the game which give little pieces of information about what is going on and if you do not collect a large majority of them good luck figuring this story out! I could make some good guesses at what I think the story is, but I could easily be wrong on these also.

2.	Difficulty â€“ 4/10 While there is one particular area of the game I thought I might never beat, the rest was relatively easy. In fact the last half of the game I did not get a single game over.

3.	Visuals â€“ 7/10 The graphics in this game are decent. If you run the graphics on a higher setting it looks pretty nice and adds a slight touch to the atmosphere which is always appreciated in a horror game. Speaking of visuals, your flashlight will be your best friend in this game. When it is dark, it is DARK!

4.	Audio â€“ 9/10 This would have to be the best aspect of this game. If you really want to experience this game play this game with the volume turned up! The game is often quite and subtle which leaves the player feeling on edge as if something is about to jump out at any moment. When the pace picks up a little though, so will the background music. You will often here the antagonist movement long before you see him and in some scenarios hearing a baddie before you see them can be life or death!

5.	Replay Value â€“ 7/10 The game is short, but there are pages of plot hidden throughout the game that once you find, are added to a scrapbook you can view at anytime. Items on the map are randomly placed each time, although it does not vary much. This game is also great fun with friends because face it, who doesnâ€™t like to see their friends pee their pants in fright. There are also steam achievements and steam trading cards to be found in this game.

6.	Final Verdict â€“ 6/10 The gameplay is very basic, the graphics are decent and the audio excels! The story is very confusing, but does not hinder the scare factor. Playing alone with the volume high is sure to give anyone some good jumps. It is a very short game but I enjoyed it all the way through.

reviewText:
A full, immersive horror experience that goes far, far beyond the simple experience of the original. This game will ease you in with beautiful scenery, haunting music and a tense atmosphere, then gradually lead into the paranormal investigation into where the player's friend has gone and what the thing that took her is. From suspenseful searches through abandoned locations, to shortlived breather moments, to intense chases, this game has all the elements needed to excel as a horror.

There are some downsides unfortunately. A lot of the scares are jumpscares, the enemy AI can be cheap at times and there are some bugs in need of ironing out. The main problem is the jumpscares, which there seem to be a lot of, in addition to the moments of genuine horror.

If you can forgive some of its cheap scares and fully immerse yourself in the heart-pounding experience that is Slender: The Arrival, you will have a short but altogether riveting time playing. Choose to get the terrifying experience over with as soon as you can or spend time gathering clues as to what happened - which in itself is an extremely interesting story.

For horror fans, this is perfect. You will dread continuing on, in fear of what is to come. At times there will be nothing, at others your worst suspicions will be confirmed and something horrible will come at you from the darkness. But always the game will be gripping and have a lot more to offer past the first playthrough, from extra content to undiscovered clues.

reviewText: Before playing this game, I've heard and knew a bit about Slender Man and other related stuff, but not much. So that said, I was curious to give this game a go, especially since I love horror games and giving myself a good scare once in awhile. Let's just say that this game did not disappoint. It was a good experience I enjoyed, which is what matters. And if I must say so, I was quite a fan of the soundtrack for this game, which I also purchased as well. I find it goes well with the game itself and definitely adds in that scare factor. It can also be creepy as well. I was impressed with the graphics. And controller support was a nice bonus too, as I was initially unsure if this game had it or not.  And finally, I think this game has a pretty good story as well, which is an important thing I look for when I play video games. This game definitely has my curiosity of Slender Man intrigued now as I'm pretty sure I'm going to be looking more into this Slender Man stuff more. All in all, I enjoyed this game and I'd recommend it, especially if you want a good scare. And keeping in mind, I played the entire game in a pitch dark room with headphones.

reviewText:
While maybe not as immersive as games like Outlast, Slender: The Arrival does an exquisite job of setting the mood to the point that the atmosphere alone can be enough to make players hesitate on moving onward through the game, only to super-charge that tension when it becomes apparent that there are very clear and frightening threats to be avoided at all costs in the midst of various isolated and lonely settings, ranging from a simple forest in the dead of night to the dark abyss of an empty mining facility and more.

Throughout the game, there are a number of moments and levels far more scary than the others, with occasionally a little silence in between to let you catch your breath. The enemies you shall be running from are frightening and very well designed, each with their own unique mechanics and characteristics.

Slender: The Arrival has a very simplistic story on the surface, starting with the player character, Lauren, visiting the isolated home of her friend Kate, only to find her missing and sets out in search of her. However, as the game progresses, small and even subliminal clues can reveal the nightmare fuel behind the horrors you witness.

Unfortunately, the game was somewhat short upon release, but a healthy dose of extended and new levels from Blue Isle Studios certainly made up for that problem. It is still not as long as games like Outlast, but the various difficulty settings, achievements and small level of randomisation in the levels will always be alluring for those with the courage to go again.

Slender: The Arrival is a worthy adaptation of the original Slender: The Eight Pages game and does an excellent job of making you feel as if Slenderman could be right behind you at any time. The tension and atmosphere are exquisite, the story is chilling and the scares are unforgettable. After all this time, I can still not get enough of this game, and can certainly recommend it to anyone looking for a good horror experience.

reviewText:
*Note: this review was written before the 2.0 update and many issues have now been fixed*

This is one of those odd games to review. You see initially i was having an enjoyable experience and wondering why this game got lower scores but now that i look back i see some of the outstanding issues. At the beginning of the game I was pretty freaked out, you know, taking my time looking around every dark corner. This was good, the opening prologue level was probably my favourite part of the experience. But after the end of this level that's when things start to fall down. Slowly as you progress through each level the fear factor actually decreases. With brighter lit enviroments as you progress the game it took away some of the worry that i had since i no longer needed to worry about what was in the dark.(BTW i love darkness in games but when you make it so dark it's impossible to navigate i have an issue) Not only does the scare factor drop with the lighting system but when i first watched the Chaser from a distance i was more laughing than scared since the animation was jerky and the AI seemed to be in a state of pants-on-head â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. This strikes me as odd though that an enemy that you will spend a lot of time looking at has crap animation while the Slenderman(the creature you'll want to spend the least time looking at) has proper and well designed animations. The other creature, Charlie, seemed to have near-non existant animations and when he was sitting still it looked more like a something from Doom where it's a 2D images worked into a 3D enviroment.
The sound design feels well done with creature and enviroment noises adding to your already tense state. But i stopped for a minute when I heard the sounds from Slender: The Eight Pages. I guess it's supposed to be a callout to the last game but this is a new game and i'd like to hear improved versions of these sounds.
Speaking of the last game, I did enjoy the Eight Pages remake level, which did a good job of calling out to the last game while still keeping a sense of originality.
Now here's the big one besides the ending, the glitches. Now I only had one real gamebreaking bug but in horror games even if a bug isn't game breaking it can still absolutely ruin the immersion for a player. For example, the first time I played the Eight Pages level I had 7 pages and was freaking out ,worrying about the Slenderman but then I saw him and was baffled when he was about to kill me and then just left. I didn't see him like a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and walked right into him and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ all happened. And I know this isn't supposed to happen since I tested the level other times. Other Slendy bugs were dying from him even though he was nowhere to be seen, him teleporting inside other objects and a weird one where he hovered above the ground. My gamebreaking bug was when I was caught by the Chaser and waited to die but the camera just sat there fixated on the Chaser's face like it had grabbed me. After a few minutes the Chaser started running away with the camera following it's face from the front. This continued for about 7 minutes before i gave up and had to restart the level.
We now come to the ending. Now I feel like I could spoil the ending here and not ruin it for you at all but I won't for the sake of fanboys everywhere. What you should know is the ending is a major cliffhanger with nothing being resolved. It just kinda ends. Maybe I could have overlooked this but with the game being obnoxiously short it makes it un-compensatable. It feels like after the ending was actually once a level just a leading to the next level and they were just like, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it we can sell it like this" and then just folded in.

So all in all

reviewText:
While the game is short, the story is strange and hard to follow, and the game is repetitive, Slender: The Arrival is still an amazing game.

You play as a woman named Lauren, who is searching for her friend Kate. While in her house, you find she has gone completely insane and has started drawing Slender Man related pictures all over the walls. Finding a message telling you to head to a radio tower, you begin to walk there, being chased by Slender Man and various 'proxies' of his along the way.

You must collect various pages left behind by Kate, then you must enter a mine and activate various generators to escape, while being chased by The Chaser, one of Slender Man's proxies. After that, you begin your ascent to the tower, and upon entering, you are chased by a skeletal figure named Charlie Matheson.

Slender: The Arrival is a great game, and the upcoming content looks fantastic. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking to get scared.
7.5/10

reviewText:
A decently put together horror game that is far better than the original Slender.

Slender games have killed any scariness to Slender-Man, but it was only a matter of time.

While the game looks absolutely amazing for a Unity game, there are frustrating aspects to it, such as the absolute â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t ai of the proxy that chases you in the tunnel, the repetitive gameplay and scares, and sprinting is slow as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, but the story is written by the team who films Marble Hornets and the soundtrack and atmosphere is pretty chilling.  The game previously had problems with optimization, but the Steam version seems to run far smoother.

For only 10 bucks, it's at least worth one playthrough, especially the Steam version, with achievements and bonus content. Beyond that though, I don't think I will ever play this outside of the new content added. The gameplay is rather repetitive with the Slender-Man's pop-up scares becoming less scary every time. Still I comend Blue Isle Studios and the rest of the team in making an enjoyable game.

reviewText: Oh man. I wanted to like this game. I'd always heard how supremely creepy the Slender mythos was, and I'd heard good things about the Eight Pages when it was free on the web (though I'd never played it). Alas. Yes, there are a few decent jump scares, but that's about it. Honestly, the most frightening thing about the game is how hot it makes my computer run. I couldn't focus on the prologue because I was too busy wondering if my PC was going to catch fire. In terms of gameplay, there's not much to it. You run around, pick up or turn on things, and try not to die. Funny thing about that, though. Running wears you out pretty fast, or something - I don't know. It's hard to say. You'll be trying to run away from something, and then you're not running fast anymore, and then OH GOD IT'S ON MY FACE. Retry. Retry. Retry. Since key objects are - in most cases - randomly generated around each level, all you can really do is hope they spawn close enough so that you can activate them before whatever thing is after you tries to kill you. Sound like Outlast? It's a lot like Outlast. Except you can't hide from things, and as far as I can tell, turning off your flashlight doesn't dissuade them from running over and clawing your face. Fun! Except not. Also, about that story: you are someone, apparently, wearing a hoodie and recording everything, because found footage, or whatever. And it seems you're trying to find your friend, or something, who apparently is a nut case and likes to draw with chalk on every surface for hours at a time in big scribbly letters. You get hints of something or whatever, but that's about it. Despite a decent score, and a few pretty vistas throughout, this game is really not worth the hour or two it takes to complete it.

reviewText: As if Slender: The Eight Pages wasn't scary enough. Slender: The Arrival has taken the original concept of the horror game and took a few more steps further. The jump-scares are certainly worth it, now that you actually HAVE to worry about Slender Man grabbing you with his tenticles. Not only that, our tall friend has a little companion, which adds on to your worries. You are no longer looking at a bleak forest each time you play. You have different levels you can get to, let it be finding the original 8 pages or turning on generators. The atmosphere has certainly become creepier, and I absolutely love it. Not to mention, you have a back story to this whole thing. It isn't like in 8 pages where you are sent off on a quest to find 8 drawings for the heck of it. This game has been promising from the start, and I'm certainly thrilled to have bought it.

reviewText: Slender: The Arrival is a simple, yet terrifying experience. Despite an unclear story, and a slightly irritating middle section, its really a fun experience. Ultimately its our anticipation that delivers our frights. The easter egg hunt-like gameplay never gets old, as on multiple stages, your objectives are placed throughout the maps at random, and your enemies movements have no logic or pattern. There just really scary. Slender himself is a pretty creepy guy. Peering around trees and waiting behind corners, he's more of a trapper than a hunter. But then there's the proxy. The proxy shows up halfway through the game and stalks you through out an abandoned mine, and without giving anything away, he's short, fast, and kind of annoying. When being stalked by Slender, running in the opposite direction usually solves the immediate issue. But the proxy is not so easily gotton rid of. Tasked with turning on a series of generators in a maze of mine tunnels, the proxy attacks head on. One may turn and face their opponate, as he charges straight at you, and narrow their flash light beam, momentarily blinding him, giving you window to run and hide. But it doesnt really work. Doing this only buys you seconds and the proxy is quick. And if you dont have enough corners to duck around, he proceeds to tackle you to the ground and throttle you, all the while you curse at your screen in anger. But the ability to see past this minor nuesance, will reward you with better scares in the latter part of the game. The Steam ending is particularly horrifying. So check out Slender: The Arrival, and keep a change of shorts nearby.\n

reviewText:
Slender: The arrival is a horror game made on the Unity engine that plays around with the Slenderman myth.  If you haven't heard of Slenderman, you must have slept under a rock for a couple of years, since this baddy has been around for a while.

The game starts you off as Lauren, a normal, teen-age girl who goes to visit a friend of hers who happens to be in the middle of the woods (Who would've thought).  But, there's a certain, horrifying exception to this friendly greeting.  Slenderman wants to join the party.  Kate, your friend, has gone missing for a while, and as you uncover her secret, you regret every thought about her.

For the most part, the game is pretty terrifying.  If you've ever played a Slender game before, you'll get the basics pretty quickly, but some of the scares will probably be less effective towards you.  There are seven levels in total, including an easter egg level that messes with your head, with two more levels to be added at a later date.  Along with the similar controls, you'll find the gameplay to be also very similar to the other Slender games, which is disappointing.  I was hoping that they would add something new or have a new mechanic that's nececessary to play, but most of the levels are usually, Collect 8 Pages"
date: or "Close all windows and doors".  It detracts from the experience
recommended: but still keeps you on the edge of your seat at all times.\n\nSlenderman isn't the only creature that is present.  Characters such as proxies

reviewText:
If you like the Slenderman character. Cool. If you liked the original indie game Slender. Cool.

Slender The Arrival is the sequel to the massively popular indie game by Parsec Productions. Which to be honest I wasn't too in to. The main problem with this game is how repetitive it is. Almost every level is finding a certain number of items, be it pages or generators. And that's pretty bad when there are only FIVE LEVELS.

The game actually has more monsters that just Slenderman, which I commend them for. However, they are rarely seen ingame, which is slightly dissapointing. But for the levels they are on. It's a nice addition.

So, overall. Slender: The Arrival isn't the worst horror game ever made, it's got really cool visuals and a decent atmosphere. But it's not the long quality experience that I expected from the game. For the price, you won't be that dissapointed. But it could be a lot better. I would say to give it a look, and judge it for yourself.

reviewText:
Pretty solid game. Short but effective. The tension builds at a steady pace right up until the end. I loved how time would pass as you progressed, going from day time to night. Was a nice touch, as was the audio. Graphics are slightly dated, but still gorgeous.

Of course it has its flaws. Maybe its intentional, but a save function would have been nice. The mine thing felt slightly out of place and a tiny bit forced (to me anyway). I ran into a couple bugs I found related to clicking letters and pausing while they were still open on the screen. Unpausing would cause the screen to go black and stay black. Happened most often at the very end of the prologue going into the next chapter. Not a huge deal, just annoying.

Overall, its a pretty awesome game and I hope to see more from the devs.

reviewText: I was really impessed with this little horror treat. Beautiful graphics, great suspense building and effective jumpscares. Only downside, was very brief, could realistically finish it in 2 hours. Took me 3.6 because I'm a thorough explorer and I died a lot... first time I saw Slender I just ran right up to him to say hi... But other than that, it's much better than expected. And well worth it at the sale price of 3.99. I would place it somewhere between The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and Outlast, as far as style and gameplay. If you like either one of those, and a good jumpscare, you'll like this one. The story seemed like a prologue, so hopefully it's just The Arrival and we'll see some fully fleshed out sequels. Definitely tracking this studio to see what they come up with next.BIG RECOMMENDATION!

reviewText:
Oooooh, Spooky Slenderman is coming to touch your butt with his ticklefingers!
But seriously, this game looked half decent in the trailers and screenshots and what not, it looked like it could make the Slender games actually scary to me, if done right. But unfortuantley, this game is not done right, far from it.

You're all familar with Slender right, the free horror game built with unity that was about you running away from the Slenderman, a tall white guy from Internet campfire stories, while collecting pages for some reason. It was ok I guess, despite it being the very defention of jumpscare fest, but it was atleast free. Not anymore.

With Slender: The Arrival now you can get chased by a tall white man while collecting pages. But with prettier graphics!
This game tries to set up a plot, starting out with you jogging threw the woods to a childhood friend's house, but when you get there she isn't there. Just a buttload of scribbles on the wall. You walk around for a while and eventually Slendypants pops his head up threw a window. Then you have to collect pages, that cause the Slenderman to attack you.

First off, for a game that's trying so hard to set up a story, it does a pretty poor job at explaining what we're doing and why we're doing it. Why do we need these pages, what could these drawings by a 4-year old tell us, and why do we want them if they make Slendy attack you? Secondly, I don't really find Slenderman himself that scary, he's just a tall white guy to me,  so it might be  the fact that I'm also very tall and pale thats putting me off. If you were more enriched in the lore of Slenderman then I guess this could be scary. Maybe.

But thirdly, and most importantly, the gameplay is just awful. I like to judge horror games partially by how much they can hold up after all the spooks end. Game's like Amnesia and Five Night's at Freddy's I managed to like as I did find them fun to play after I stopped being scared. But Slender isn't one of those games, every single level is walking around, collecting or turning on X of a certain object, while Slenderman jumpscares you, or on one level, you get chased by a human. Rather than running away, from it, you get to stand still for a second and flash your light at it stop it from running at you.
Over and over and over. This game was so grating and just plane boring to play  that I couldn't even bring myself to get to final level. The point where I stopped playing was when I burnt to death in a forest fire level, where slenderman appeared several times but I didn't notice because he blened in with the trees.

In conclusion, just stick with the original Slender and all it's spinoff games if you found them scary, rather then throwing 10 bucks at this and getting basically the name thing with some pretty graphics.

reviewText: This game...I very much like this game. Slender: The Arrival is a basic survival horror game that relies heavily on jumpscares. But that is not a bad thing. I found myself being caught off guard at moments when I believed Slender nor his Proxies were going to show up. The way this game has impeccable and building atmosphere definitely adds to the stress and pressure the game puts out, also while increasing the creep factor. The way it has subtle story telling, and links itself in a major way to its predecessor, Slender: The Eight Pages, is amazing. I would definitely recommend this game to Slender fans and horror fanatics alike. 8.75/10

reviewText: NOTE: I had to set some custom launch options to et the lighting to work AT ALL in this game, so if you're looking or a game to quickly install and work flawlessly right away, you should wait until these errors are resolved by the devs.\n\nThis game does a good job at reviving The Slenderman as a creepy and mysterious being, unlike the Slenderman we're bombarded with on all corners of the internet, generally in the form of poorly written crepypastas or a pony fan-fictions. This game takes the basic gameplay mechanic from the original Slender: The Eight Pages and gives it some beautiful scenery, smooth graphics, and new environments and scenarios to make it a fresh, (and eery) new experience. The story is very cut and dry, but the lack of backstory creates a feeling of unknowing, which adds to the uneasy and creepy atmosphere. When I bought this I was expecting a slightly modified version of Slender: The Eight Pages, quite honestly, but when the screen turned bright and I was suddenly in the middle of a beautiful forest at dawn, I was slightly surprised. I was even more suprised as I suddenly realized it was dark, as I walked deeper into the forest with no flashlight. The atmoshphere this game creates right off the bat is amazing, and left me wanting to play more. I would definitely reccomend this game despite its bugs.

reviewText:
Slender: The Arrival is essentially a big overhaul of its original game, Slender: The Eight Pages. Gameplay is generally the same as the original: roam the darkness with only a flashlight in search of varying objectives to finish the stage while evading the Slenderman in order to have a quick, exciting horror experience.

The further you progress in each stage, the more the ambience intensifies (making it constantly more unsettling :D). Progress also effects how often he will appear and try to get you via teleporting around corners/infront of you. But now the game is a little more adventure-like with stage proggresion having inbetween sections during the day where you run to the next zone safely".

The scares are very exciting most of the time because the creepy environment sets you up with eerie sound effects and ambience
date: making you constantly expect him to be around each corner! However
recommended: the scares definitely rely on his instant appearances ie jumpscares. That being said
hoursPlayed: (for some players) this will make his reoccuring appearances lessen in later progression because he appears more frequently and you get more used to it.\n\nThe plot is pretty subtle and is only fully revealed through various notes you progressivley hunt for (not the objective ones) so theres a little bit of collectable finding to do as a side task for future playthroughs in order to understand the events completely. In the end I personally enjoyed it and would recommend it to those who liked the original or anyone looking for a short horror game and doesn't mind some jumpscaring :P"

This game is pretty impressive; it uses elements I really don't like such as dark areas to explore and the use of flashlight.

The controls and graphics are definitely the best part; the maps are brilliant in color and lighting which really sets the mood and creates a fear factor.

I'd pay $10; usually on sale for $2 which is a steal!

With a much larger dev team than the original Slender: The Eight Pages, and a story written by the creators of the wonderful Marble Hornets YouTube series, you'd think it would be pretty awesome. But unfortunately, while the graphics may be very beautiful, and while the atmosphere may at first feel very foreboding and creepy, the actual scares aren't very, well, scary. The Slender Man isn't a threat, he's an annoyance. To overcome him, you simply have to look away from him, and keep your distance. As long as you adhere to those two rules, there is NO WAY you can fail. And The Chaser isn't any better. All you have to do is simply shine your flashlight at The Chaser repeatedly to stun her, and then run away. These two characters aren't enemies, they're pests. The only things standing between you and your goal in a horror game are the antagonists. The point of a horror game is to be scary. When you can avoid your antagonists so easily, it makes the game not scary. And when your horror game isn't scary, that mean's you have completely failed. Not only are the scares lackluster, but so is the gameplay and story. The missions consist of finding eight items or activating six generators while avoiding the Slender Man or Chaser (which, like I said before, isn't very difficult), or simply walking from point A to point B. The objectives are very repetetive, and combined with the lack of tension aside from a few cheap jump scares, the missions are boring and not very fun. Slender's story fails as well because everything feels very pointless. Why is your character trying to find eight pages? Why doesn't she just turn around and leave? Why are we supposed to believe that a radio tower is a safe place aside from the fact that the game just tells us that it's safe? All of these questions (and more) are never answered. The writers of the story (Troy Wagner, Tim Sutton, and Joseph Delage) said that the development team warped and manipulated their original story which, if true, might explain the poor narrative quality. Combine the lack of scares, shallow story, repetetive gameplay with the short time it takes to complete the game (45 minutes-1 hour), and you have one huge letdown of a game.

reviewText:
A fantastic remake of the original Slender game.
The graphics and sounds have been remade and Slenderman has never looked better. The maps are big, well detailed and beautiful.

But the game has lost some of the original charm that made it so awesome. The scariest thing about the original Slender game was its simplicity. Find 8 pages, that is it. Slenderman was truly frightning and I often crapped my pants when he appeared. The graphics are beautiful, but the downside is that you are not as frightened. You can easily break Slendy. He will rarely ever appear in front of you. All you need to do is walk straight and only look back a couple of times. I spent 40 minutes walking around the 8 pages level searching for the last page, with Slendy behind me. Not once did I feel scared and when he appeared in front, i just turned around and said nope.avi.

Granted, the abandoned mine was compensation. That was a truly horrific experience.

Worthy remake of the original, with beautiful visuals and sound, but a part of its original charm is gone.

reviewText:
On normal difficulty this game can be completed in around 3 to 4 hours. Factor that in when deciding if the price is worth it.

Having said that, this is a disturbing little jaunt into the Slender Man nightmare. The creators deserve a pat on the back for making such a picturesque and harrowing atmosphere.

Gameplay is extremely straight forward: explore, read letters, do a certain thing a certain number of times, and (most important of all) RUN AWAY.

I would love to see more of the same, except this time with a decent budget and a better variety of tasks. Puzzles, riddles, maybe a little combat with 'infected' people.

All in all, this is worth throwing a few quid at. Play it in the dark with head phones on.

reviewText:
Two years after this game was released, it's still an incredible, chilling experience.

Slender: The Arrival is THE Slender game; a simple story with a backstory that leaves you with more questions than answers... but that's what makes the mystery all the more enticing. BEAUTIFUL graphics with such simple details. You view the world through a video camera in a 'Blair Witch Project' atmosphere.

The environments are stunning during the day; a beautiful forest in what looks like upstate California with fall leaves, sunlight filtering through the branches and lensflares on your camera. But then at night, the beauty is tarnished as you're alone and hunted in an ebony black wasteland of wood, isolated and with nothing but a flashlight to protect you.

Slender isn't the ONLY one after you in this game either...

A bit of a scavenger-hunt game with find-it tasks, but it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Slenderman approves!

I recommend it if you somehow haven't played it or even if it has been as long of a time as it was for me.

reviewText:
There's a common complaint among fans of horror video games that very few of the titles in the genre have any real subtlety anymore. It's hard not to agree after having played such games as Dead Space or any recent Silent Hill game. Slender: The Arrival at least attemps to reverse that trend by waiting until around the twenty-minute mark to actually show the eponymous character on screen. Even so, The Arrival is little more than an amalgamation of boring horror cliches that do very little to actually frighten the player once they've figured out the game's basic mechanics.

The main premise of Slender is that you are a guy... or a girl... looking for someone named Katie. It's not exactly very big on the details, and I guess the developers wanted to leave those up to the player so that they wouldn't have to go through the trouble of writing an actual plot. The player spends most of the game wandering through a forest that's roughtly the size of an average high school auditorium looking for clues" that look more like the drawings of a troubled 9-year-old who thinks he's "so hardcore". All the while being pursued by some faceless guy in a suit that was likely ripped off from Agent 47.

Let me step away from the idiotic premise for a moment
date: so that I can harp on how technically unimpressive the game is. Notwithstanding the fact that it's only $3 on sale (honestly
recommended: it's not even worth that much). The Arrival looks like just another generic "indie" game that was developed by a team of college kids in their mothers' basement. The lighting is godawful; the player's flashlight is the only light source that actually illuminates the surrounding area. Aside from the player character's head bobbing back and forth
hoursPlayed: there is no animation to speak of. Slenderman appears out of view and causes some cheap distortion in the player's view. That's it. Nothing else. Even the game's indie credentials don't absolve it from the fact that it was obviously developed on a shoestring budget by a bunch of people who have no idea what they're doing. The "soundtrack" consists of a handful of boring ambient tracks that try desperately to create a tense and oppressive atmosphere
voteText: but manage to fail at both
helpfulPercent: only serving to exacerbate just how boring the game actually is.\n\nAside from all of that
votesHelpful: between the bad lighting
votesTotal: poor level design
votesFunny: and sparse information
commentsCount: the game's main objective is too difficult
column16: and the game itself too uninteresting to inspire the player to rise to the challenge. If you have a friend or family member who is into Slenderman and also under the age of twelve
column17: this might be a worthwhile purchase. Otherwise

reviewText:
Slender is a fairly simple game; it is not complex whatsoever.

You can customize your settings such as keybinds and graphics, but be warned, you cannot change your keybinds inside the game. You can only do it from the tiny launch box that appears as soon as you start to load into it.

The game does not work well with virtual game controllers, supposedly, unsure if true game controllers will work it. I have no game controllers - however all my character did for two days straight was spin in aimless circles and was unmovable.

If you want some mediocre horror; this is for you. The creepy sounds might make you itch the back of your neck while trying to figure out what it was, but overall, it's really just a solid->gradient slenderman.

reviewText:
Slender: The Arrival is a short game where the player takes control of Lauren who is searching for her friend, Kate, in the middle of the forest controlled by the omnipresent Slender Man. With players viewing the action through Lauren's video camera, the game is at first deeply atmospheric but flaws that hinder the experience soon become apparent.

The majority of Slender: The Arrival involves the player walking through dark, open environments where the Slender Man can appear from anywhere. On a first playthrough, Slender: The Arrival is very tense, with each step forward making the player feel uneasy. The overall atmosphere is bleak with finely presented environments, eerie music and collectible notes helping construct an unsettling experience. Players familiar with Slender Man lore will undoubtedly find the experience more unnerving than those who are not.

Despite the rich atmosphere and tangible tension, Slender: The Arrival turns into a trivial, almost dull game once the Slender Man actually appears. The first time a player observes the Slender Man, their inital response is most likely one of fright. However, each time the Slender Man appears on screen, the frightning effect is diminished. Players will soon realise that the game consists of a foe that can teleport around the environment to provide cheap jump scares and little more. It soon becomes tedious and if one were to turn around and see the Slender Man merely floating toward them as if it were on a wire, it all becomes easily managable.

Slender: The Arrival is good during the first hour but it soon becomes a tedious collection of jump scares which fail to fright and interactions with a folkloreish entity that strips away all creditable mystery or menace. Even harder difficulty settings fail to improve the frights in a lacklustre horror experience.

reviewText:
I preordered this game and, even though at the time it says 0 hours, I played it a bunch when it wasn't on Steam yet. Thankfully, my code worked for Steam, so now I am fine. Let's begin.... This is the BEST Slenderman game on the market.

Seriously, it is the best Slenderman game. It borrows a lot from Marble Hornets, which is what really made mythos. Heck, it's even written by Troy, Tim, and Josh. Before I go on any further, if you didn't like Eight Pages, you will not like this. If you liked Amnesia, you will like this. Now, as for the game....

Hunt for items while Slenderman hunts you down. In one later mission, he has a Proxy helping him which ADDS to the already stressful nature of the game. It's randomly generated, which makes looking fun! The Slenderman himself appears tall, imposing, and the sound effects + camera static REALLY makes him feel terrifying. In fact, everything about the visual appearance of the Slenderman in Arrival is perfect.

The game IS short, though, and a bit repititve. For $10, you'll get what you paid for.

reviewText:
Slender: The Arrival is good...for an indie game.

It's probably the best Slenderman game to come out of the hoard of other games that tried to capitalize on the success of the original, but that's not saying much.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed Slenderman: The Eight Pages, and I even liked the idea of having Slenderman's aggression dependent on the amount of pages you'd collected. It was a fresh idea, but it wasn't exactly compelling or fleshed-out enough to warrant spending any more than 30 minutes to an hour with it.

Slender: The Arrival aims to lenghten, and provide greater context to the original idea, but it hardly manages to do either successfully.

The story is presented to the player through signs and notes that are scattered around each environment in the game, and its your job to collect them and determine what happened in Slenderman Land. Who (or what) is Slenderman? What happened to the family who lived there? Who are they, and why is Slenderman targeting them? The game definitely raises more questions than it answers, so be prepared for dissapointment if you were expecting a decent payoff. Even if you do manage to piece it together, the story is textbook horror, and it doesn't offer any significant surprises or revelations.

The game is dissapointingly short as well, clocking in at 2 hours or less on normal difficulty, depending on how often you need to retry the difficult sections of the game.

If you go into to Slenderman: The Arrival with low expectations, you might find it enjoyable. The visuals look nice, and the audio design is suitably creepy when it needs to be. In all honesty, it's impressive when you consider that this is Blue Isle Stuidio's first game, but at the end of the day though, Slenderman: The Arrival is undone by its cryptic storytelling and ridiculously short length. I'd only recommend that you pick it up when it goes on sale.

reviewText: As a large fan of horror games, I have a huge problem with them. Most horror games rely on the initial shock of whatever it is you're dealing with. In this case, the whatever it is you're dealing with is Slender Man. He's creepy and extremely startling. He'll scare you to death the first run through this game. Slender, or better yet the mechanics that make up Slender, rely on the unknown and the confusion that's conjured in your own head. Being lost AND hunted make for a stressful situation. And they only lay it on thicker as you continue. But after the first playthrough, you know exactly what to expect and you know exactly how Slender and his hooded companion are going to react to you and your actions. The shock wears off and you're left only a little startled every time your camera lense gets a bit of static. All of that boils down to the lack of any real replayability. Nothing is left to keep you wondering except a few collectables. If you are looking for story in this game, almost the entire narrative is found within the many collectables found in the game. The collectables and the narrative found within those collectables adds a very miniscule amount of replayability. Which brings me to my conclusion; I think this game is very worthy of its $9.99 price tag, but doesn't have much more to offer after the experience.

reviewText:
This is pretty much any old slender game,
but with a story.

You start out heading to your friend Kate's house to help her sell it, but you were delayed due to unforseen complications.
Namely, a tree fell down and blocked your path. Anyway, you decide to go out venturing into the woods, its day-time, so you don't encounter the Slender Man. Once you get to Kate's house, its already dark, and you go inside. The first thing you see when inside is a huge drawing on the wall, the drawing consists of trees, and Slender Man. You have to find a flashlight, and its usually in the Dining Room, but it can sometimes be found in the Living Room or the... Lounge..? I don't know what to call it, but by that time you can see the Slender Man, but he only appears outside. You find a key in a bedroom upstairs, and you must go down a dark hallway to get to the room that the key opens. Once inside, you see basically a mural to the Slender Man, there are little notes on the wall and everything. There is a desk with a page on it that says To the woods"

reviewText:
I preordered this game and, even though at the time it says 0 hours, I played it a bunch when it wasn't on Steam yet. Thankfully, my code worked for Steam, so now I am fine. Let's begin.... This is the BEST Slenderman game on the market.

Seriously, it is the best Slenderman game. It borrows a lot from Marble Hornets, which is what really made mythos. Heck, it's even written by Troy, Tim, and Josh. Before I go on any further, if you didn't like Eight Pages, you will not like this. If you liked Amnesia, you will like this. Now, as for the game....

Hunt for items while Slenderman hunts you down. In one later mission, he has a Proxy helping him which ADDS to the already stressful nature of the game. It's randomly generated, which makes looking fun! The Slenderman himself appears tall, imposing, and the sound effects + camera static REALLY makes him feel terrifying. In fact, everything about the visual appearance of the Slenderman in Arrival is perfect.

The game IS short, though, and a bit repititve. For $10, you'll get what you paid for.

reviewText: As a large fan of horror games, I have a huge problem with them. Most horror games rely on the initial shock of whatever it is you're dealing with. In this case, the whatever it is you're dealing with is Slender Man. He's creepy and extremely startling. He'll scare you to death the first run through this game. Slender, or better yet the mechanics that make up Slender, rely on the unknown and the confusion that's conjured in your own head. Being lost AND hunted make for a stressful situation. And they only lay it on thicker as you continue. But after the first playthrough, you know exactly what to expect and you know exactly how Slender and his hooded companion are going to react to you and your actions. The shock wears off and you're left only a little startled every time your camera lense gets a bit of static. All of that boils down to the lack of any real replayability. Nothing is left to keep you wondering except a few collectables. If you are looking for story in this game, almost the entire narrative is found within the many collectables found in the game. The collectables and the narrative found within those collectables adds a very miniscule amount of replayability. Which brings me to my conclusion; I think this game is very worthy of its $9.99 price tag, but doesn't have much more to offer after the experience.

reviewText:
When I first played Slender: The Eight Pages however many years ago it was now, I was instantly smitten. And also really scared. So being the typical consumer that I like to think I am, I bought this game before it came to everyone's beloved platform, Steam. Let me say one thing: It has come so far from then.

New levels, bug fixes, level edits. The list goes on. All of these things have made the game a more enjoyable experience for players like me. It is not comparable to something like Outlast, at least for me, due to the factors of human nature brought up in that game (humans have the capabilities to be far more monstrous than any supernatural beings, in my humble opinion). However, the game is still terrifying. And short. I am saddened to say that I think my time playing may have been my whole playthrough. Not on hardcore, but on regualr mode. That said I had played through the game before, so much of it was already known to me.

All in all, a top-notch Slenderman game. As a horror game, probably around the middle to upper-middle class, the kind that still would have qualified for the guillotine in the French Revolution but only by the length of their necks. As a story, its a bit weak. Gameplay is your typical run and hide without the hiding and with a lot more of the running. I would recommend getting it on sale, probably for $5, although I could still recommend it at $7.50.

reviewText:
Let me simply tell you that this game is not good.

Is it horrible? No. It is worth $9.99? Absolutely Not.

I picked this game up on sale for $0.19 and even then I can't recommend this game.

The first few moments of the game, I thought this seems mysterious and interesting. Unfortunately five minutes later, it was not. You discover the plot that your friend Kate went missing and want to find out what happened to her. Except I did not want or care to find out what happened to her. There was later a flashback but that didn't even make me want to care about to Kate.

I played through this game and it doesn't get any better. It's very repetitive and boring. You walk around and try to avoid the slenderman, who is not scary at all, and attempt to find various objects. There is no combat and the world isn't even explorable...it's a linear game.

Unfortunately the steam community tries to hype up horrible games and give them good reviews. Please don't buy this game, it only encourages more terrible games to be made.

reviewText:
If you're not into scary games, don't play it. It's easily the scariest game I've ever seen.

You play as Lauren, a moderately normal woman who has the worst luck this side of breaking a mirror when her car crashes into a recently felled tree. From there, she has to walk - by the time she arrives at her friend's house, Kate has disappeared. After a while, she unlocks the door to her friend's house, to find the walls covered with notes.

She hears Kate scream, and runs out the back door. Eventually, she finds a journal, filled with ramblings about a man named 'C.R..'

It has a story made by the people who made Marble Hornets, the web series that inspired the original Slender, and the graphics are beautiful and terrifying, depending on where you are. Maybe even both. The jump-scares were enough to make me nearly â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ myself at several points, and the final level is just creepy as all hell, so... do I recommend it? Hell, yes I recommend it!

Look, just... buy the game. You know you want it.

reviewText:
VERSION 2.0 Review:

Slender The Arrival has certainly had shifts in quality between updates, and I am pleased to say that v2.0 is literally perfect. First off, the new levels are TERRIFYING. And I mean Amnesia terrifying, Homestead and Memories (the two new levels) are very memorable and are a great addition to the game. The Arrival looked amazing upon release, and yet v2.0 makes it look even better. There are better textures and models in some areas, and Genesis now looks fantastic rather than being a carbon copy of The Eight Pages with some of The Arrival's entities. The biggest flaw to S:TA before v2.0 was the gameplay; it was ridden by bugs and problems such as the overly frustrating mine level, terrible interaction physics, and the simply god awful fire sequence. Everything has been fixed in 2.0. The interaction is now smooth and comfortable, the mine level's main NPC (the source of the frustration) has been perfected, and the fire sequence is now an intense but fair climax.

Some gamers may be turned off by the ten dollar price tag for a 3 hour game, but guys, come on. A group of inexperienced indie developers worked their asses off for this and they deserve the money. Not to mention, this is one of the horror greats in gaming - I liked it almost as much as the Amnesia games. This is also the first game by Blue Isle Studios, and for an indie game group's first game this is amazing.

Overall it's an amazing game with a great story. Give it a go.

reviewText:
Rather short game, and suffers from few flaws that are just stupid. If you pick up a document, the game tells you that it can always be viewed from the Main Menu. However, this resets your game and in case you were in the middle of a chapter, you have to start all over again. Chapters aren't overly long, so it's not a big loss, but it's still tedious and annoying. Though the documents aren't needed after reading them up once, they are in every other game similar to this, thus most players will fall for this trap due to natural player instinct.
Another issue I must address is the running. It's way too slow. When you wanna run away or just get somewhere fast, and you aren't sure if your character is walking or running, something is wrong indeed. I never actually figured out if there was a hidden stamina meter, or if the running was just bugged, but at times it seemed to slow down really badly, and it can get pretty annoying pretty fast. Especially in those scenes where a player's natural instict is to run, it doesn't really add to the feeling that you feel like a flea in a tarpuddle.

But is Slender: The Arrival a bad game then? Absolutely not. And to its credit, I must say that the parts that are meant to be scary really work! This game manages to create a frightening and eerie mood without relying solely on jumpscares like so many other horror games do. Plus the game randomizes certain elements (such as the locations of key items), so that there is at least something new on each playthrough. I wouldn't necessarily pay 10â‚¬ from it, but it's definately worth to try for a horror game fan.

I do recommend this game to any horror game fan, but with a little bit of caution =) The menu trap" becomes a neglectable issue once you know it
