reviewText:
The game remains very true to the youtube series such as Darkharvest00, EMH, marblehornets etc, which I love, as I am a huge fan of the slendy series. The settings are all very similar, and the camera overlay was a nice touch.

It has a good atmosphere, with creepy sound cues and lighting. This could have been improved with more buildup of tension as seen in amnesia and in the slender vlogs, where you anticipate that something will happen around every corner. Still, the environments are well designed, and the graphics are very good, including shadows, hdr and a nice touch of colour distortion from slendy at various points in the game. The game also runs very smoothly, unlike the first game (8 pages) which had serious fps issues.

The jump scares are fantastic, and really make the game. To see slendy in front of you and then turn around to find him behind you is terrifying, and is a good change from other horror games where you can just lock the door and know that you will be alerted to the monsters arrival when he tries to break it down.

The proxy is a questionable addition in my opinion, and not well designed. While its good to have another enemy to run from, there seems to be no way of getting rid of her or to combat her. She will just stand there indefinetley when you point the torch at her, and when you runaway, she will suddenly appear out of nowhere behind you and kill you. Initially she is scary, but after the 5th time she gets you in a few minutes, she becomes more of an annoying obstacle than a terrifying monster.

Overall, while the game does have its faults, it is still a fantastic horror game, and also a must have for any fan of the slenderman mythos and videos.

reviewText: Slender the Arrival does it's best to give you a creepy experience but it just keeps falling flat. It is a very nonintuitive game. It's standard first person shooter controls (without the shooter) and places you in the creepy woods of a park. One of its main shortcomings is that it lacks the ability to deliver the story properly. We are supposed to make assumptions about everything. Assumptions that are probably wrong. I kept finding clues about a person and assumed that person might be me. Then it took reading some backstory in a walkthru to discover that I was a completely different person baguely mentioned in one of the notes. The first few times I played it I was throughly creeped out and some of the presentation helped with that. It uses a method of steady-cam" view that looks like you are filming this which can also be viewed that you are someone else watching this person's footage (a la Blair Witch Project
recommended: or Paranormal Activity). What you find does heighten the tension and when odd things are seen it really creeps you out. But then it feels like a grind. Where am I supposed to go next you ask. Oh over there. Wait I think I've found everything. Do I go back? Where to next? There is a decisivve lack of direction and instruction. It gave me a goal but the goal was so vague that I didn't know whether I was finished nor did I know if I was finding the right things. I wandered around doing nothing SLOWLY for a half hour and then quit the game. Why? HEre is the biggeswt problem. There is no save feature. It saves once you finish "THE CHAPTER". I was stuck in the "prologue" for days. Every time I tried it I had to start from the beginning. So by the 15th time I tried finding all the clues or whatever I was not afraid of the woods nor the creepy things. So far all I've seen are creepy things but none of them are harmful things. Don't get me wrong. This game has figured out that in horror you can't just in-your-face all the horror like Dead Space or Doom 3 etc. But it has to be subtle. But it hasn't fuguyred out pacing
voteText: furthering the adventure. It also relies a lot on camera glitches and sound effects and music. THose things are very important in horror. But in this case I am never sure if these elements actually appear in the game world or just in the game "providing atmosphere" like I'm being followed around by a 40s radio SFX guy banging pots together and breathing heavily. It reminds me of the scares in the movie The Ring where Ehren Krueger hit us over the head with loud noises and in your face weird cut in pictures to scare us and when you got to the end all you could say was "Huh?"\nI would be interested if this studio tried it again with horror as this was an improvement over its predecessor but it still isn't there. The controls and gameplay are still lacking. Your RUNNING mode isn't much faster than your WALKING mode. You can neither jump nor go in water so you feel like a child in one of those wheelie guides. The story needs a bit of polish. There needs to be a definite indication who I am and what I'm doing and how far I've gotten with it. Because leaving it up to my imagination is unacceptable in a game. How am _I_ supposed to know when I am done with a chapter if I don't know what I'm supposed to be looking for

reviewText:
Probably the scariest game I have ever played. Don't expect complex gameplay or intense puzzle-solving or anything like that, you should just expect to wet your pants after a while. Most of the game is just spent exploring and looking to collect a set number of items (similiar to the mod this game was based off), however don't think that means this game is boring. The game developers excel in knowing how to properly f%$k your mind while you attempt to avoid being scared. I actually have difficulty playing this game for very long at once, because I get so nervous.

One of the most outstanding parts of this game is its replayability. You would think that a game like this would have little to none; you would be wrong. The developers again excel at finding ways to make each playthrough unique, hiding items in different locations and having scares randomly generated during your playthrough. Just because you were safe in an area before means nothing the next playthrough!! One of the only downsides to this is that the game is a little bit more difficult than you would expect. Finding the locations of the items before getting killed (or giving up in fear of having a heart attack) can be frustrating when their locations change every time you die, however there is usually a pattern that can be discerned eventually.

While this might not be the most 'fun' or 'addictive' scary game I've ever played, I would say hands-down it is the 'scariest'. I still enjoy watching my girlfriend play it and watching her scream when she turns around and slenderman is standing right behind her. If you are someone who enjoys torturing yourself through voluntary fear, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!

reviewText:
Being a huge horror game fan, Slender was one of my favorite series of games. There was never really a GREAT Slender game, but there was also never really a terrible Slender game. Slender: The Arrival is Parsec Production's (the original creator of Slender: The Eight Pages) first attempt at a story-driven horror game. Let me say, it's definitely an experience.

The story's introduction is kinda slow, but the game's pretty so its no big deal. Your friend, Kate, has been missing. You travel to her house in the middle of the forest, and when you get there, the doors are open and the house is a mess. After finding clues and her room key, you see that Kate was terrorized by something for quite some time. Obviously, there's a TON more to the story, missing children, looking for pages (of course), and you even get to play as Kate for a mission.

These missions aren't always Collect 8 Pages". Sometimes it's just looking for clues
date: other times you have to start generators
recommended: but I won't spoil any more.\n\nSlender: The Arrival is a spot on attempt at a horror game. I pooped myself and jumped out of my seat a couple times
hoursPlayed: and I can't wait to see what else Parsec Productions and Blue Isle have for this game or the series.\n\n9/10"

reviewText:
Worth a play if you like creepy games. This game isn't terribly twisted or gross like a lot of horror games, it's just all about keeping your anxiety level high! Don't get me wrong, the story and atmosphere keep you creeped out, but what's really creepy is that, for much of the game, the slender man can appear anytime, anywhere, and all you can do is run as fast as you can in the opposite direction.

It only takes a couple of hours to play through, if you're not trying to get 100% everything, but it's worth the ride.

A negative would be that the story isn't all that interesting or coherent. Maybe it would make more sense if I 100%-ed the game and was able to read all the notes laying around, but really, a game should make sense without requiring that.
